title: TSB adds £125 switching bonus to its 5pc current account - but it's short-lived
text:
0.00 0.00 
Customers have four weeks to grab a cash bonus for switching to its '555 Classic Plus' account that also pays 5pc interest 
TSB will pay new customers £125 if they switch to its "555 Classic Plus" account that also pays 5pc interest and generous cashback rates - but the deal ends in a few weeks. 
Customers have until November 2 to apply for the account, which also pays 5pc cashback on contactless spending , and must do so via websites, Moneysupermarket.com or MoneySavingExpert.com, which are part of the same company. 
And the bonus is only paid if you open the account using the current account "switch guarantee", that closes your old account for you and transfers direct debits automatically. 
This service also guarantees any payments accidentally made to your old account are redirected for 36 months after the switch. 
Once the account is open, customers need to register two direct debits and pay in £500 before the £125 bonus is paid, and must do so within 28 days of the switch. 
• Halifax balance transfer best-buy now pays up to £35 cashback 
• The best bank account switching offers 
= Verdict = 
TSB's cash bribe is short-lived and can be beaten elsewhere. 
First Direct, the online and telephone-only bank, pays £150 to customers who use the "switch guarantee" via the same two websites, MoneySavingExpert.com or Moneysupermarket.com. 
Clydesdale Bank also pays £150 to customers who switch their current account before November 30. But you must pay in £1,000 and set up two direct debits before the incentive is paid. The account also pays in-credit interest of 2pc on balances up to £3,000. 
Halifax also matches TSB's offer with a £125 bonus for customers who switch, who don't need to go through a third-party website. 
And you could be left worse-off by switching just for a cash bonus, warned Andrew Hagger from Moneycomms, the financial analyst. 
"You'll get a quick cash hit but you could end up with a bank account that’s not suitable for your day-to-day needs," he said. 
• Should you ditch the Santander 123 account when its fee jumps to £60 per year? 
But the TSB Classic Plus account is one of the best on the market. It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) pays a high interest rate of 5pc on balances up to £2,000 - beating any easy-access savings account. 
But high overdraft fees and debit card charges while abroad could cancel out these perks, Mr Hagger warned. 
He added: "It’s pretty much a rule of thumb for most accounts - good credit interest equals expensive agreed overdrafts."
